This algorithm is broken in a number of ways.

1) It can take an arbitrarily large amount of time for some inputs (e.g. to sort 2^32 numbers). This is because it uses a recursive algorithm, meaning it will recurse as many times as necessary, no matter how large the number is. A more efficient way is to use a divide and conquer algorithm. For example, to sort the numbers 1-2^32, you would divide the numbers into two groups:
1-2^8 1-2^16
... 1-2^4 1-2^2 1-2^1
... 1-2^0
Then sort 1-2^8, then 1-2^16,..., 1-2^0.

2) It does not guarantee to sort the array. For example, if the array is [[1], [2], [3], [

The explanation was useless for me. Can you explain it in a sentence or two?

The idea is that you're given a bag of things, one thing at a time, and you can only get one thing out at a time. You're also allowed to put one thing in at a time, but you can't replace the thing you take out.
The task is to see if you can get everything into a single container, like a bag, that can be taken out one at a time. If you can't, you've failed.

I think you're right, but it's not immediately obvious that you can do a single "move one ball" operation, which doesn't move the whole array, but only moves one

Explanation
The algorithm requires that the elements in the array arr be randomly ordered.  If the elements are ordered in non-decreasing order already, the algorithm will be unable to determine if a sorted array is possible.

The algorithm starts by determining if there are any empty slots in arr.  If there are no empty slots, the algorithm proceeds to determine if the number of elements in arr is even.

If the number of elements is even, the algorithm returns True.

If the number of elements is odd, the algorithm performs a right shift operation on the entire array.  The shifted elements are then removed from the array, and the algorithm proceeds to determine if the number of elements is even.

If the number of elements is even, the algorithm returns True.

If the number of elements is odd, the algorithm performs a right shift operation on the entire array.  The shifted elements are then removed from the array, and the algorithm proceeds to determine if the number of elements is even.

The algorithm terminates if the number of elements is even.

 Quicksort

The first solution looks pretty good. I'm not sure why you are using a static method, though. I guess there could be a performance difference. I think it might be a little bit clearer if you used the keyword public in place of the @ since it is more commonly used to denote public methods. Also, there's no need to add the def keyword to the method definition.

The second solution is also pretty good. I'm not sure why you're using 2 if statements and not a single one. Also, I think it would be more clear if the test in the if statement was on the result of the operation.

Finally, I don't see anything wrong with the third solution. It's a good way to test if a sequence is sorted.
